terms.definition: Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a service provider and accessed via the internet
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems
Enterprise Resource Planning - integrated software systems that manage and automate core business processes across an organization
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to revert to previous versions and track revision history
A security method that restricts system access and document modifications based on the user's role within an organization
The process of connecting different software applications through their APIs to enable data sharing and synchronized functionality
The ability for multiple users to simultaneously work on and edit documents with changes visible instantly to all participants
A chronological record of all document changes, user actions, and system events that provides accountability and compliance tracking
A centralized digital storage system that organizes, manages, and provides access to an organization's documents and files
The use of software to automatically route documents, assign tasks, and trigger actions based on predefined business rules
Material Safety Data Sheets - documents that provide detailed information about chemical substances and their safe handling procedures
Formal records and reports that demonstrate adherence to regulatory requirements, industry standards, and internal policies
Pre-formatted document structures that provide consistent formatting and required fields for specific types of documentation
A unified system that consolidates multiple functions, data sources, and user access points into a single interface or location
A data management concept ensuring that everyone in an organization references the same, most current version of information or documents
